docinfo.docinfo:doc-heading: DIVISION 1 ENFORCEMENT OF WRITS OF EXECUTION GENERALLY [rr 39.1–39.20]

heading.title: DIVISION 1 ENFORCEMENT OF WRITS OF EXECUTION GENERALLY [rr 39.1–39.20]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 39 ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS [rr 39.1–39.52]

leg:heading.title: ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENTS [rr 39.1–39.52]

entry.emph: Division 1 — Enforcement of Writs of Execution Generally — Rules 39.1–39.20

row.entry: This Division deals with the procedure for obtaining a writ of execution, the process of execution and application of the proceeds of the sale of property seized in the execution of judgments.

entry.emph: Division 2 — Enforcement of Writs against Land — Rules 39.21–39.28

row.entry: This Division deals with the enforcement of judgments by execution against real property, the process of sale and the application of proceeds.

entry.emph: Division 3 — Enforcement of Writs against goods etc — Rules 39.29–39.33

row.entry: This Division regulates the process of execution involving the sale of goods.
This Division contains rules governing the enforcement of money judgments by garnishee orders made under ss 101 and 109 of the CP Act.
This Division sets out the procedure for obtaining charging orders under ss 101, 118 and 119 of the CP Act.
This Division contains miscellaneous rules relating to execution of an order for costs, orders relating to partnership property and orders affecting persons who are not parties to proceedings.

This Part applies to all courts in Schedule 1 of the CPA except the Industrial Court and the Industrial Relations Commission and rr 39.21–28 do not apply to the Local Court, Small Claims Division: see r 1.5 and Sch 1.
The rule is based on the former SCR Part 44.
Affidavit in support of application for writ of execution ‥ [r 39.3]
Affidavit that no debt due or accruing ‥ [r 39.40]
Application for a writ of execution ‥ [r 39.2]

Costs of prior execution not enforceable without cost assessor’s certificate ‥ [r 39.47]
Court refusal to make garnishee order ‥ [r 39.38] , [39.38.5]
Lien or claim of third person ‥ [r 39.41]
Notice required for certain attached debts yet to accrue ‥ [r 39.43]

Orders authorising entry to premises by Sheriff – special circumstances ‥ [39.52.5]

Service of a copy of the writ ‥ [r 39.18]
Sheriff to be informed of persons in occupation of land ‥ [r 39.3A]
Value below which Sheriff may not seize tools of trade ‥ [r 39.46]
When writ may not be executed ‥ [r 39.19]
Writs in aid of another writ of execution ‥ [39.1.35]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: DIVISION 1 ENFORCEMENT OF WRITS OF EXECUTION GENERALLY [rr 39.1–39.20]

leg:heading.title: ENFORCEMENT OF WRITS OF EXECUTION GENERALLY [rr 39.1–39.20]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 39.1] r 39.1 Circumstances in which issue of writ requires leave (cf SCR Part 44, rule 2)

leg:heading.title: Circumstances in which issue of writ requires leave (cf SCR Part 44, rule 2)

p.text: A writ of execution may not be issued in the following circumstances except by leave of the court:
if there has been any change in the persons entitled or liable to execution under the judgment, whether by assignment, death or otherwise,
if the judgment is against the assets of a deceased person coming to the hands of an executor or administrator after the judgment took effect, and the writ is against those assets or any of them,
if a person’s entitlement under the judgment is subject to fulfilment of a condition,
if the writ is a writ for the possession of land,
if the writ is against property in the hands of a receiver appointed by the court,
if the writ is against property in the hands of a sequestrator,
if the writ is in aid of another writ of execution.
See also section 134 of the Civil Procedure Act 2005 with respect to stale judgments.
If leave is required, it may be applied for in the notice of motion for the issue of the writ of execution.
The motion for leave must be supported by the following evidence:
evidence that the applicant is entitled to proceed to execution on the judgment,
evidence that the person against whom execution is sought to be issued is liable to execution on the judgment,
if the judgment is for the payment of money, evidence as to the amount due on the date of the motion,
if subrule (1)(a) applies, evidence as to the change which has taken place,
if subrule (1)(b) or (c) applies, evidence that a demand to satisfy the judgment has been made on the person liable to satisfy it and that the person has not satisfied it.
Subrule (1) does not limit the operation of any other Act or law that requires leave for the issue of a writ of execution.
The relevant approved forms are as follows:
Writ of possession — for enforcement of a judgment or order for possession of land:
Form 59 (Notice of Motion).
Form 60 (Writ).
Writ for restitution
Form 61 (Notice of motion)
Form 62 (Writ)
Writ of delivery — for enforcement of a judgment or order for the delivery of goods:
Form 63 (Notice of Motion).
Form 64 (Writ).
Writ for the levy of property — for enforcement of a judgment or order for the payment of money:
Form 65 (Notice of Motion).
Form 66 (Writ).

Where the judgment creditor has died or become bankrupt the application may be made ex parte: Mercer v Lawrence (1878) 26 WR 506 . The executors and trustees will not be able to issue a bankruptcy notice against the judgment debtor until they obtain leave: Ex parte Woodhall (1884) 13 QBD 479 . It is not necessary that they be added as parties. However, where the judgment is sought to be enforced by a method which does not come within the definition of "writ of execution", for example the appointment of a receiver, the proper course is for them to seek to be added as parties: Re Shephard (1889) 43 Ch D 131 ; Salt v Cooper (1881) 16 Ch D 553. Where the judgment debtor has died notice of the application should be given to the personal representative: Re Shephard, above; Thompson v Gill [1903] 1 KB 760. Where there has been an assignment of the whole of the judgment debt the application may be made ex parte: Re Bagley [1911] 1 KB 317. Assignment of part only of a judgment debt does not, however, alter the parties entitled to issue execution as execution can only be levied in respect of the whole of the judgment: Forster v Baker [1910] 2 KB 636; [1908–10] All ER Rep 554; Rothschild v Fisher [1920] 2 KB 243; Chung Kwok Hotel Co Ltd v Field [1960] 3 All ER 143; [1960] 1 WLR 1112. Death or retirement of a member of a partnership does not effect an alteration of the parties within the meaning of the rule: Re Frank Hill [1921] 2 KB 831.

In its strict common law meaning, execution was the process whereby the sheriff, authorised by one of the common law writs, seized and realised property to obtain the means to satisfy the entitlement of a judgment creditor: Re a Company [1915] Ch 520 at 527. Courts could make other orders to aid the enforcement of judgments. Commonly these orders were species of equitable relief. They included orders for the appointment of receivers, particularly over property interests that were not recognised at law, and orders made without the intervention of any writ for levy of property or other formal execution process: DM & BP Wiskich Pty Ltd v Saadi (SC(NSW), Bryson J, 16 February 1996, unreported, BC9600188). Orders of this type were referred to as “equitable execution”: Wills v Luff (1888) 38 Ch D 197 ; Levasseur v Mason & Barry Ltd [1891] 2 QB 73 ; Re Shephard (1889) 43 Ch D 131 . Examples of orders by way of equitable execution include: the appointment of a receiver of a fund held in court: Westhead v Riley (1884) 25 Ch D 413; the appointment of a receiver over a reversionary interest under a will: Fuggle v Bland (1883) 11 QBD 711 ; the appointment of a receiver over the income of a trust fund: Webb v Stenton (1883) 11 QBD 518 ; an injunction to restrain payment by a third party to a judgment debtor: Bullus v Bullus (1910) 102 LT 399 ; Gillet v Gillet (1890) 14 PD 158. These examples have in common the feature that the orders relate to species of property that could not have been the subject of execution under common law process: DM & BP Wiskich Pty Ltd v Saadi (NSWSC, Bryson J, 16 February 1996, unreported, BC9600188). Under s 101(2) of the CPA execution is available against real and personal property, including choses in action and equitable interests. Rules 40.2–40.8 of the UCPR contain additional measures permitting execution by sequestration and committal in certain circumstances.

Execution requires physical seizure of the debtor’s goods. Upon delivery of the writ the sheriff acquires a legal right to seize the goods: Boucher v Wiseman (1595) Cro Eliz 440; Horton v Ruesby (1686) Comb 33; Re Davies; Ex parte Williams (1872) LR 7 Ch App 314; [1861–73] All ER Rep 960. That right takes priority over any subsequent transfer or assignment of the property by the judgment debtor: Samuel v Duke (1838) 3 M & W 662; Woodland v Fuller (1840) 11 Ad & El 859; except an assignment or transfer to a bona fide purchaser for value. Property in the goods seized remains in the execution debtor — unless and until they are duly realized in the process of execution: Re Clarke [1898] 1 Ch 336 . But entry into possession gives the sheriff a special property in the goods and that property interest is sufficient to maintain an action in trespass or trover. Giles v Grover (1832) 9 Bing 128 ; Re Davies; Ex parte Williams , above. Until the goods are sold the execution creditor’s rights are analogous to those of a secured creditor. They have a legal right to have the goods sold and to be paid out of the proceeds: Re Davies; Ex parte Williams, above.

Leave will not be given when the statutory period of limitation has expired (see s 17 of the Limitation Act 1969) unless there has been an acknowledgment or part payment by the debtor (Thurlow v Jordan (1887) 8 ALT 138) Nor will leave be given where the judgment was obtained despite non-compliance with relevant statutory requirements: Jones v Jaggar (1886) 54 LT 731 . The court may consider the state of accounts between the parties and the existence of any cross-claim which will extinguish the judgment amount (Dale v Powell (1911) 105 LT 291 ; Kayley v Hottersall [1925] 1 KB 607 ), although it is not obliged to permit the set-off: Byrant v Torkington (1897) 13 TLR 315. Dismissal of an application under this rule does not preclude a second application but unless it is supported by new matters not raised in the first application it will be unsuccessful: WT Lamb & Sons v Rider [1948] 2 KB 331; [1948] 2 All ER 402 .

level.toc-caption: [39.1.30] Receiver — execution against property held by

p.text: Legislation cited in [39.1.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 r 39.1(1)(e).

heading.title: Receiver — execution against property held by

p.text: Leave is necessary under r 39.1(1)(e) because otherwise a sheriff who seizes goods in the possession of a court appointed receiver would be guilty of contempt: Lane v Sterne (1862) 3 Giff 629; Edwards v Edwards (1876) 2 Ch D 291.

level.toc-caption: [39.1.35] Writs in aid of another writ of execution

heading.title: Writs in aid of another writ of execution

p.text: Included within the description "writs in aid of another writ of execution" are the writ of assistance, the writ of restitution, the writ of venditioni exponas, the writ of distringas nuper vice comitem, and the writ of capias ad satisfaciendum. The last three writs are virtually obsolete.

The writ provided a more convenient procedure than the ordinary process of contempt for the enforcement of an order for the possession of property: Daniell's Chancery Practice (1914) 8th ed, Vol 1, at 833. So far as land is concerned the writ has been superseded by the writ of possession (Hall v Hall (1878) 47 LJ Ch 680 ), but it is still available to obtain recovery of chattels. The writ may be issued in cases where a writ for specific delivery has proved, or will probably prove, fruitless. The application for leave may be made ex parte and should be supported by evidence showing service of the writ of specific delivery and non-compliance with it: Webster v Taylor (1854) 18 Jur 869. The writ may, for example, appoint a receiver of the property — especially where there is a danger of it being removed from the jurisdiction: Wyman v Knight (1888) 38 Ch D 165; Re Taylor [1913] WN 2121.

Where, after entry of the sheriff under a writ of possession, or after the plaintiff has been put in possession by the sheriff, the defendant forcibly or by stratagem resumes possession of the property, the plaintiff may have a writ of restitution: Pitcher v Roe (1841) 9 Dowl 971 . This is the normal procedure and not an application to commit for contempt: Alliance Building Society v Austen [1951] 2 All ER 1068 . Application may be made ex parte. Similarly, where a plaintiff has entered under judgment which has been set aside the defendant may apply to set aside the writ of possession and ordering the plaintiff to vacate with leave then (or subsequently on ex parte application) to issue a writ of restitution: see cases cited in Halsbury’s Laws of England, 3rd ed, vol 16, para 104(n). Similarly, where possession has been wrongfully obtained — either under an irregular writ of possession, or in excess of the terms of the writ of possession (ibid).
The writ is not a separate process but is part of the process of execution by fi fa: Hughes v Rees (1838) 4 M & W 468.

The writ issues to compel the sheriff to sell where they have delayed or refused to proceed: (Cameron v Reynolds (1776) 1 Cowp 403). The writ may also authorise a sale at the best attainable price where the sheriff is unable to realise the true value of the propoerty: Slye’s case (1619) Godb 276; R v Bird (1679) 2 Show 87; 89 ER 811.

heading.title: Writ of distringas nuper vice comitem.

p.text: The writ issued on a change of sheriff. It was directed to the sheriff in office to distrain on their predecessor to compel the sale of seized goods (Clerk v Withers (1704) 2 Ld Raym 1072), or to pay the proceeds of execution to the judgment creditor: Helbroke v Beaumont (1579) Ch Cas in Ch 123.
The writ commands the sheriff to take the defendant into custody until the judgment is satisfied. As a result of s 130(c) of the CPA the writ is no longer available to enforce a judgment or order.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 39.2] r 39.2 Application for writ of execution

leg:heading.title: Application for writ of execution

p.text: An application for a writ of execution in respect of a judgment is to be made by way of notice of motion.
Unless the court orders otherwise, a notice of motion under this rule:
may be dealt with in the absence of the parties, and
need not be served on the judgment debtor.
The application must indicate the extent (if any) to which the judgment debt has been satisfied under any writ of execution, garnishee order or charging order issued by the court.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 39.3] r 39.3 Affidavit in support of application for writ of execution (cf DCR Part 34, rule 13)

leg:heading.title: Affidavit in support of application for writ of execution (cf DCR Part 34, rule 13)

p.text: Unless the court orders otherwise, an applicant for a writ of execution must file an affidavit in support of the application, being an affidavit sworn not more than 14 days before the date of filing.
In the case of a writ for the possession of land, the affidavit in support:
must identify any persons (other than parties to the proceedings) who were in occupation of the whole or any part of the land:
as at the time the originating process was filed, or
if the claim for possession arises from an amendment to the originating process, as at the time the amendment was made,

and, if any such person was in occupation of the land pursuant to a right of occupation under a residential tenancy agreement within the meaning of the Residential Tenancies Act 2010, must contain a statement to that effect, and
in relation to each such person:
must state that the person’s occupation of the land is not to be disturbed, or
must state that the person is no longer in occupation of any part of the land, or
must state that the person has been served with a notice pursuant to rule 6.8 and that the time allowed for the person to apply to the court to be joined as a defendant has now passed,
as the case requires, and
if the claim for possession of the land arises from a default in the payment of money, must give the particulars required under subrule (2A) , and

must state the source of the deponent’s knowledge of the matters stated in the affidavit concerning the occupation of the land and any default in the payment of money referred to in paragraph (c), and
must state whether costs are claimed and, if costs are claimed and the costs claimable are fixed by law, the amount (not exceeding the amount so fixed) that is claimed for costs.
The costs fixed by law referred to in paragraph (e) include costs that are fixed under section 329(1)(c) of the Legal Profession Act 2004.

[subr (2) am Amendment 11 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[22], effective 8 December 2006; Act 27 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 2.58, effective 4 July 2007 ; Amendment 29 of 2009 Sch 1[12], effective 8 October 2009; Amendment 44 of 2011 Sch 1[3], effective 15 April 2011 ; Amendment 47 of 2011 Sch 1[2], effective 9 September 2011]
The particulars required for the purposes of subrule (2)(c) are:
if judgment has been entered for the payment of money in addition to possession of the land — each of the following particulars:
the amount of the judgment debt,
the amount of interest accruing on the judgment debt to date,
any payments made by or on behalf of the judgment debtor after judgment was entered,
the current amount owing taking into account the matters referred to in subparagraphs (i) , (ii) and (iii) , or
if judgment has been entered only for possession of the land — each of the following particulars:
the amount owing following the default,
any payments made to date to reduce the amount owing,
the current amount owing taking into account any such payments.
[subr (2A) insrt Amendment 47 of 2011 Sch 1[3], effective 9 September 2011]
In the case of a writ for the delivery of goods, the affidavit in support:
must state which goods have not been delivered to the plaintiff since the time the judgment was given, and

must give particulars of any payments that the defendant has made to the plaintiff in respect of the goods or state that no such payments have been made, as the case may be, since the time the judgment was given, and
must state the address at which the goods are alleged to be located.
[subr (3) am Amendment 19 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 1[18], effective 7 December 2007]
In the case of a writ for the levy of property, the affidavit in support:
must state the amount payable under the judgment, together with any costs and interest payable in relation to the judgment, as at the date of swearing of the affidavit, and
must state the address or addresses at which property belonging to the judgment debtor may be located, and

if the judgment was entered as a result of the filing of a cost assessor’s certificate, must include a statement to that effect, together with a statement to the effect that the determination set out in the certificate:
is not subject to any suspension under section 377(1) of the Legal Profession Act 2004 that has not been ended under section 377(2) of that Act, and
is not subject to any suspension under section 386 (1) of the Legal Profession Act 2004 that has not been ended under section 386(2) of that Act.
[subr (3) am Amendment 11 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[23], effective 8 December 2006]

Any application by the judgment creditor for a writ of execution in relation to a judgment debt that has been the subject of an instalment order that has ceased to have effect may not be granted unless the judgment creditor has filed an affidavit as to the judgment debtor’s failure to comply with the order.

A reference in this rule to a residential tenancy agreement within the meaning of the Residential Tenancies Act 2010 is taken to include a reference to a residential tenancy agreement within the meaning of the Residential Tenancies Act 1987 as in force before its repeal.
[subr (6) insrt Amendment 44 of 2011 Sch 1[4], effective 15 April 2011]

The approved form for a Notice of motion for writ for possession of land is Form 59 . Form 61 is the approved form for a notice of motion for a writ of restitution. Form 63 is the approved form for a Notice of motion for writ for delivery of goods. Form 65 is the approved form for a Notice of motion for writ for levy of property.
Legislation cited in [39.3.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 39.3(2)(a).

If a mortgagee becomes entitled to exclusive possession of a rented property, the tenants must be given not less than 30 days notice to vacate by the sheriff: Sheriff Act 2005 s 7A; Residential Tenancies Act 2010 s 122. A mortgagee who applies for a writ of possession must advise the court if the property is subject to a residential tenancy: r 39.3(2)(a) and Form 59 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 39.3A] r 39.3A Sheriff to be informed of persons in occupation of land

leg:heading.title: Sheriff to be informed of persons in occupation of land

p.text: This rule applies to:
a writ for the possession of land, and
a writ for the levy of property in respect of which a notice of sale of land has been filed as referred to in rule 39.22(1)(b) .

If the Sheriff so requests, the judgment creditor or other person for whose benefit the writ has been issued must inform the Sheriff as to whether any person is in occupation of the land pursuant to a right of occupation under a residential tenancy agreement, within the meaning of the Residential Tenancies Act 2010.
[subr (2) subst Amendment 44 of 2011 Sch 1[5], effective 15 April 2011]

A reference in this rule to a residential tenancy agreement within the meaning of the Residential Tenancies Act 2010 is taken to include a reference to a residential tenancy agreement within the meaning of the Residential Tenancies Act 1987 as in force before its repeal
[subr (3) insrt Amendment 44 of 2011 Sch 1[6], effective 15 April 2011]
[r 39.3A insrt Amendment 29 of 2009 Sch 1[13], effective 8 October 2009]

The sheriff may require a mortgagee to advise whether the property is subject to a residential tenancy. If a mortgagee becomes entitled to exclusive possession of a rented property, the tenants must be given not less than 30 days notice to vacate by the sheriff: Sheriff Act 2005 s 7A; Residential Tenancies Act 2010 s 122.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 39.4] r 39.4 Order in which writs for the levy of property to be dealt with (cf SCR Part 44, rule 8; Act No 9 1973, section 108)

leg:heading.title: Order in which writs for the levy of property to be dealt with (cf SCR Part 44, rule 8; Act No 9 1973, section 108)

p.text: Writs for the levy of property against the same judgment debtor are to be enforced by the Sheriff in the order in which they are received by the Sheriff, regardless of the order in which they were issued.

As between execution creditor and execution debtor the date of issue of the writ determines its priority: Re Davies; Ex parte Williams (1872) LR 7 Ch App 314; [1861–73] All ER Rep 960. As between the execution creditor and third parties the writ binds the property of the debtor from the date of its delivery to the sheriff (Thompson v De Lissa (1881) 2 LR (NSW) 165) unless the goods are not seizable at common law in which case physical taking possession is necessary: Johnson v Pickering [1908] 1 KB 1; [1904] All ER Rep 1004. As between different execution creditors priority is determined by the precise time of delivery of the writ to the sheriff (Thompson v De Lissa, above; Hutchinson v Johnson (1787) 1 Term Rep 729; Drewe v Lainson (1840) 11 Ad & El 529) unless execution has been suspended on the earlier writ (Hunt v Hooper (1844) 12 M & W 664) and unless one of the creditors is the Crown, in which case the Crown has priority even though the goods have already been seized under a prior writ: Jeanes v Wilkins (1749) 1 Ves sen 195; R v Wells (1807) 16 East 278 ; Giles v Grover (1832) 9 Bing 128. However if execution on a writ is suspended because the judgment has been set aside the priority of the original writ is not lost if the judgment is subsequently reinstated: Bankers Trust Co v Galadari [1987] 1 QB 222.

If several writs are handed to the sheriff at the same time there is no priority. If the sheriff has received multiple writs any proceeds of sale must be applied according to the priority of the writs even though the sheriff realized the property under the authority of them all: Barnard v Wright (1874) 5 AJR 66; Beath v Anderson (1883) 9 VLR (L) 41 ; Drewe v Lainson (1840) 11 Ad & El 529; Rimmett v Lawrence (1850) 15 QB 1004. If the sheriff receives further writs after seizing goods, the goods are also bound by the later writs without a further seizure: Jones v Atherton (1816) 7 Taunt 56.

First delivered writs may lose their priority in the following circumstances. If the writ has been issued fraudulently in order to protect the debtor's property (Bradley v Wyndham (1743) 1 Wils 44); or upon a judgment fraudulently obtained against creditors (Imroy v Magnay (1843) 11 M & W 267; Christopherson v Burton (1848) 3 Exch 160; 154 ER 798); if there is undue delay in execution (Lovick v Crowder (1828) 8 B & C 132; Payne v Drew (1804) 4 East 523); if there is fraudulent collusion to keep the earlier writ unexecuted (Theobald v Cotterell (1853) 20 LTOS 212); if instructions are given not to execute until further order (Hunt v Hooper (1844) 12 M & W 664); or until a future day (Kempland v Macauley (1791) Peake 95); or unless other writs come in (Pringle v Isaac (1822) 11 Price 445).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 39.5] r 39.5 Property to be sold promptly (cf SCR Part 45, rule 5)

leg:heading.title: Property to be sold promptly (cf SCR Part 45, rule 5)

p.text: Subject to this Division, any property to be sold under a writ for the levy of property must be put up for sale as soon as practicable, having due regard to the interests of each of the parties and to the need to avoid of the sacrifice of the reasonable value of the property.

If the judgment debt is outstanding the sheriff must sell seized goods and cannot simply deliver them to the execution creditor: Thomson v Clerk (1596) Cro Eliz 504; 78 ER 754. The sheriff can accept payment of the debt after seizure of goods and if full satisfaction of the debt is tendered the sheriff must not proceed with the sale: R v Bird (1679) 2 Show 87; 89 ER 811. Payment of the amount for which execution is levied discharges the writ: Gregory v Cotterell (1855) 25 LJQB 33.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 39.6] r 39.6 Order in which property to be sold (cf SCR Part 45, rule 4; Act No 9 1973, section 110; Act No 11 1970, section 62A)

leg:heading.title: Order in which property to be sold (cf SCR Part 45, rule 4; Act No 9 1973, section 110; Act No 11 1970, section 62A)

p.text: If it appears to the Sheriff that the value of the property affected by a writ for the levy of property is greater than the amount outstanding under the judgment debt, the Sheriff may not cause to be sold any more of the property than is sufficient to satisfy the judgment.
Subject to subrule (3), property is to be sold:
in such order as seems to the Sheriff best for the speedy satisfaction of the judgment without undue expense, and
subject to paragraph (a), in such order as the judgment debtor may direct, and
subject to paragraphs (a) and (b), in such order as seems to the Sheriff best for minimising hardship to the judgment debtor or any other person.
Land must not be sold before any other property unless:
the judgment debtor so requests, or
the Sheriff is satisfied that the land should be sold before the other property in order to minimise hardship to the judgment debtor or some other person.
Legislation cited in [39.6.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Conveyancing Act 1919.
The following property may be taken in execution:

Choses in action: (Horwood v Murdoch (1879) 5 VLR (L) 435); but not a right to sue in a personal action (Evans v Crosby (1893) 5 QLJ 95); nor an undelivered cheque: Courtay v Vincent (1852) 15 Beav 486.
Dividends: Unpaid dividends in the hands of a receiver may be seized: Evans v Stephen (1882) 3 LR (NSW) (L) 154.
Emblements: Evans v Roberts (1826) 5 B & C 829; Scorell v Boxall (1826) 1 Y & J 396.

Equitable interests: The debtor's interest in property under a will (Re Cox; Perpetual Trustee Co Ltd v Cox (1903) 3 SR (NSW) 356) and in land (Trustees Executors and Agency Co Ltd v Butler [1905] VLR 650 ) may be seized.

Fixtures: Fixtures which the judgment debtor has a right to remove may be seized in execution (Poole's case (1703) 1 Salk 368; 91 ER 320) but not those which he or she has wrongfully removed or lost his or her right to remove: Farrant v Thompson (1822) 5 B & Ald 826; Dumergue v Rumsey (1863) 2 H & C 777; Richardson v Ardley (1869) 38 LJ Ch 508.

Hire purchase agreement: The hirer's interest in goods the subject of a hire purchase agreement may be sold in execution unless the agreement is expressed to terminate upon seizure of the goods in execution: Wylie v Nisbet (1895) 21 VLR 7 ; Jelks v Hayward [1905] 2 KB 46; Moffitt v Seller (1963) 80 WN (NSW) 378.

Judgment debt: The sheriff may seize a judgment obtained by the debtor against a third party but he or she must execute upon that judgment and may not assign it: Horwood v Murdoch (1879) 5 VLR (L) 435.

Leasehold interests: Leasehold interests in land are subject to the writ. After the sale the purchaser must bring his or her own action to eject the debtor: R v Deane (1680) 2 Show 85; Taylor v Cole (1789) 3 Term Rep 292. The sale does not work a forfeiture of the lease unless the judgment debtor connives in the sale: Doe d Carter (1799) 8 Term Rep 300; and see Croft v Lumley (1855) 24 LJQB 78.
Money: At common law, money could not be seized in execution: Collingridge v Paxton (1851) 11 CB 683. See now s 106(2)(b) of the CPA.

Real estate: Land and interests in land, equities of redemption and powers capable of exercise for the benefit of the judgment debtor may be taken in execution: ss 10 , 13 of the Judgment Creditors' Remedies Act 1901; s 174 of the Conveyancing Act 1919.
Shares: Daley v Cooper (1888) 3 QLJ 104.
Ships: A ship may be seized in execution (Union Bank of London v Lenauton (1878) 3 CPD 243) even though the debtor owns only a share in it: The James W Elwell (1921) P 351.

Third party's goods: The goods seized must be those of the debtor. Goods which are the subject of an uncompleted gift to others may be seized (Winchelsea v Maidstone (1691) 4 Mod Rep 51) but not goods the subject of an uncompleted contract of sale (Tompkinson v Russell (1821) 9 Price 287; Deacon v Kingdon (1931) SASR 271) nor goods which have been accepted in satisfaction of debts due: Newman v Cardinal (1862) 2 F & F 840. Goods of which the debtor is trustee (Re Morgan; Pillgrem v Pillgrem (1881) 18 Ch D 93 ; Colonial Bank of Australasia v Cooper (1876) 2 VLR (L) 41), bailee (Manders v Williams (1849) 4 Exch 339; [1843–60] All ER Rep 545), or pledgee (Coggs v Bernard (1703) 3 Salk 268; R v Cotton (1751) Park 112; Houlditch v Desanges (1818) 2 Stark 337) are not available for execution.

The sheriff may lawfully enter the defendant’s premises or those of any stranger to which the defendant’s goods have been removed: Semayne’s case (1604) 5 Co Rep 91; 77 ER 194; Bixop v White (1600) Cro Eliz 759. But the sheriff may be liable in trespass for entering a stranger’s land if no goods are found there: Cooke v Birt (1814) 5 Taunt 765 ; Southam v Smout [1964] 1 QB 308 . The sheriff may only enter the debtor’s dwelling house by peaceable means: Ryan v Shilcock (1851) 21 LJ Ex 55 ; Crabtree v Robinson (1885) 15 QBD 312; [1881–5] All ER Rep 1109 ; Nash v Lucas (1867) LR 2 QB 590. The restriction only relates to the actual dwelling house of the debtor and the sheriff may break into other premises after entry has been requested and denied: Penton v Brown (1664) 1 Sid 186; Hodder v Williams [1895] 2 QB 663; [1899] All ER Rep 1028 . Once the sheriff has obtained lawful entry they may break open inner doors and cupboards without prior demand: R v Bird (1679) 2 Show 87; 89 ER 811; Lee v Gausel (1774) 1 Cowp 1 ; Hutchinson v Birch (1812) 4 Taunt 619 .

Entry upon the premises where the goods are, and an intimation of an intention to seize them, will constitute a valid seizure: Bissicks v Bath Colliery Co Ltd (1878) 3 Ex D 174. A seizure of part of the goods of the debtor in the name of the whole is a seizure of them all: Cole v Davies (1698) 1 Ld Raym 724; and see Johnson v Pickering [1908] 1 KB 1; [1904] All ER Rep 1004. The sheriff is not bound to leave an officer continuously in possession and a failure to do so does not necessarily constitute an abandonment of possession which will entitle other creditors to take possession of them: Re Murphy (1927) 27 SR (NSW) 503; 44 WN (NSW) 189 ; Re Hughes (1850) Legge 659; Bagshawes Ltd v Deacon [1898] 2 QB 173; Lloyds and Scottish Finance Ltd v Modern Cars and Caravans (Kingston) Ltd [1964] 2 All ER 732. The sheriff will retain notional possession of the goods if the debtor or some responsible person in the premises agrres not to remove the goods. After such an agreement the sheriff is said to be in "walking possession": Watson v Murray & Co [1955] 2 QB 1; [1955] 1 All ER 350; National Commercial Bank of Scotland Ltd v Arcam Demolition & Construction Ltd [1966] 2 QB 593; [1966] 3 All ER 113; Federal Bank v Kretschmann (1886) 7 LR (NSW) 183.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 39.7] r 39.7 Sale to be by public auction (cf DCR Part 35, rule 5; LCR Part 30, rule 15)

leg:heading.title: Sale to be by public auction (cf DCR Part 35, rule 5; LCR Part 30, rule 15)

p.text: Subject to rule 39.13, property sold under a writ for the levy of property must be sold by public auction, by the Sheriff or by an auctioneer appointed under rule 39.8, to the highest bidder.
Property must not be sold by public auction for a price substantially below its approximate market value, as fixed by the Sheriff under rule 39.10.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 39.8] r 39.8 Auctioneer (cf SCR Part 45, rule 6; DCR Part 35, rule 3A; LCR Part 30, rule 13A)

leg:heading.title: Auctioneer (cf SCR Part 45, rule 6; DCR Part 35, rule 3A; LCR Part 30, rule 13A)

p.text: If the nature and apparent value of property to be sold under a writ for the levy of property is such that it appears to the Sheriff that it is reasonable to sell the property, the Sheriff may appoint a duly qualified auctioneer to sell the property.
[subr (1) am Amendment 9 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[17], effective 9 June 2006]

An auctioneer appointed to sell any property under a writ for the levy of property must, as soon as practicable after the Sheriff advises that the auctioneer’s services will not be required in respect of the writ, or otherwise requests an account of the auctioneer’s charges, advise the Sheriff of the amount of those charges to date.
If, after the appointment of the auctioneer, it appears to the Sheriff that it is not reasonable to proceed with the sale, the Sheriff may direct that the property be withdrawn from sale.
[subr (2A) insrt Amendment 9 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[18], effective 9 June 2006]

An auctioneer appointed by the Sheriff to sell property under a writ for the levy of property must as soon as practicable after receiving any money under the writ pay the money to the Sheriff, less the amount of any charges payable to the auctioneer in respect of the writ.
[r 39.8 am Amendment 9 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[16], effective 9 June 2006]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 39.9] r 39.9 Sale to be arranged so as to obtain highest prices (cf SCR Part 45, rules 5, 7 and 8; Act No 11 1970, section 59)

leg:heading.title: Sale to be arranged so as to obtain highest prices (cf SCR Part 45, rules 5, 7 and 8; Act No 11 1970, section 59)

p.text: For the purpose of obtaining the highest prices for the property, the Sheriff:
must ascertain what appears to the Sheriff to be the best place for the sale to be held, and
must cause the sale to be held at the place so ascertained.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 39.10] r 39.10 Approximate market value (cf SCR Part 45, rule 7; DCR Part 35, rule 8; LCR Part 30, rule 6)

leg:heading.title: Approximate market value (cf SCR Part 45, rule 7; DCR Part 35, rule 8; LCR Part 30, rule 6)

p.text: Before selling property under a writ for the levy of property, the Sheriff must fix the approximate market value of the property, having regard to all the circumstances of the case, but need not disclose that value to any other person before the sale.
For the purpose of fixing such a value, the Sheriff:
may require the judgment creditor to furnish the Sheriff with any information known to, or reasonably capable of ascertainment by, the judgment creditor in respect of the property, and
may engage a suitably qualified and experienced valuer to provide the Sheriff with an opinion as to the value of the property if the nature and apparent value of the property so warrant.

If the judgment creditor unreasonably fails to furnish any information referred to in subrule (2)(a), the Sheriff must report the failure to the court, and may refuse to proceed further towards the sale of the property.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 39.11] r 39.11 Postponement (cf DCR Part 35, rule 6; LCR Part 30, rule 16)

leg:heading.title: Postponement (cf DCR Part 35, rule 6; LCR Part 30, rule 16)

p.text: The Sheriff may from time to time postpone the sale of property under a writ for the levy of property, or require any auctioneer appointed to sell the property to postpone any such sale, if the Sheriff thinks it proper to postpone the sale:
to avoid a sacrifice of the reasonable value of the property, or
to comply with a request by the judgment creditor for the postponement.

If the date to which the sale of property is postponed under subrule (1) falls after the date on which the writ would otherwise expire, the date of expiry of the writ is postponed to the date of the postponed sale.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 39.12] r 39.12 Suspension of execution by judgment creditor (cf DCR Part 34, rule 8; LCR Part 30, rule 7)

leg:heading.title: Suspension of execution by judgment creditor (cf DCR Part 34, rule 8; LCR Part 30, rule 7)

p.text: If, at any time before property is seized under a writ for the levy of property, the judgment creditor:
requires the Sheriff, by notice in writing, to suspend execution of the writ, or
requires the Sheriff, by a subsequent notice in writing, to resume execution of the writ,
the Sheriff must comply with the requirement.

If, at any time after property is seized under a writ for the levy of property, the judgment creditor (having entered into an arrangement with the judgment debtor with respect to the Sheriff’s withdrawal and re-entry into possession of the property and notified the Sheriff of the arrangement):
requires the Sheriff, by notice in writing, to withdraw from possession of the property and suspend execution of the writ, or
requires the Sheriff to re-enter into possession of the property and resume execution of the writ,
the Sheriff must comply with the requirement.

If, at any time after property is seized under a writ for the levy of property, the judgment creditor (not having notified the Sheriff of an arrangement referred to in subrule (2)) requires the Sheriff, by notice in writing, to withdraw from possession of the property and suspend execution of the writ, the judgment creditor is taken to have abandoned the execution, and the Sheriff must withdraw from possession of the property.

For the purposes of subrule (3), a request to postpone the sale of property under a writ for the levy of property is not a request to withdraw from possession of the property or to suspend execution of the writ.

The Sheriff’s duty under this rule to resume execution of a writ for the levy of property (the original writ) is subject to the Sheriff’s duties under this Part with respect to any other writ for the levy of property that had been issued against the same judgment debtor when execution of the original writ was suspended and, for that purpose, any other such writ is to be executed, and the proceeds of sale dealt with, as if that other writ had been received by the Sheriff before the original writ.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 39.13] r 39.13 Sale by private treaty (cf SCR Part 45, rule 11; DCR Part 35, rule 8; LCR Part 30, rule 18)

leg:heading.title: Sale by private treaty (cf SCR Part 45, rule 11; DCR Part 35, rule 8; LCR Part 30, rule 18)

p.text: If, at a public auction, the highest bid of property to be sold under a writ for the levy of property is substantially below their approximate market value, as fixed by the Sheriff, the Sheriff or (if the Sheriff so approves) the auctioneer may sell the property by private treaty.
The Sheriff must not approve a sale of property by private treaty at a price substantially below a fair value determined by the Sheriff.
In determining a fair value for the property for the purposes of subrule (2), the Sheriff:
must take into account all the relevant circumstances, including but not limited to:
the approximate market value of the property fixed by the Sheriff, and
the amount of the highest bid for the property at the public auction, and
the likelihood or otherwise of there being a higher bid if the property were again put up for sale by public auction, and
must not determine a fair value that is substantially below the amount of the highest bid for the property at the public auction.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 39.14] r 39.14 Conditions of sale (cf DCR Part 35, rule 9; LCR Part 30, rule 19)

leg:heading.title: Conditions of sale (cf DCR Part 35, rule 9; LCR Part 30, rule 19)

p.text: The Sheriff may sell property under a writ for the levy of property, or require any auctioneer appointed to sell such property:
on terms as to payment that the purchaser must pay:
an amount equal to at least 10% of the purchase price by way of deposit forthwith on the sale, and

the balance of the purchase price within such period, not exceeding 2 days after the sale (in the case of goods) and 6 weeks after the sale (in the case of land), as the Sheriff may determine prior to the sale, or
on terms as to payment that the purchaser must pay the whole of the purchase price forthwith on the sale.
If a sale of property is partly of goods and partly of land, the goods may be sold on the same terms as to payment as the land.
The Sheriff may require payment to be in cash, by bank draft or, if the Sheriff so approves, by credit card.
If payment is made by credit card, any charge made to the Sheriff or auctioneer in respect of the payment is to form part of the costs of the execution.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 39.15] r 39.15 How proceeds of enforcement to be applied (cf Act No 8 1901, sections 9 and 17; LCR Part 30, rule 20)

leg:heading.title: How proceeds of enforcement to be applied (cf Act No 8 1901, sections 9 and 17; LCR Part 30, rule 20)

p.text: The proceeds of enforcement of a writ for the levy of property are to be applied as follows:
firstly, to the Sheriff to cover the Sheriff’s fees and expenses in executing the writ,
secondly, to the judgment creditor to satisfy the judgment debt,
thirdly, to the judgment debtor as to any amount remaining.

If the Sheriff receives writs for the levy of property (whether from the same or from different courts) in relation to more than one judgment creditor, the judgment creditors are to be paid from the proceeds of enforcement of the writs in the order in which the writs were received by the Sheriff.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 39.16] r 39.16 Account (cf DCR Part 34, rule 9; LCR Part 30, rule 8)

leg:heading.title: Account (cf DCR Part 34, rule 9; LCR Part 30, rule 8)

p.text: On the request of the judgment creditor, or of any person who claims that his or her property has been sold by the Sheriff under a writ for the levy of property, the Sheriff must give that judgment creditor or person:
a report of any sale under the writ, and
an account of:
the proceeds of the sale and any other money received under the writ, and
the Sheriff’s fees and expenses in relation to the writ, and
the manner of disposal of the proceeds or other money.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 39.17] r 39.17 Sheriff may require security for costs of execution (cf DCR Part 34, rule 7; LCR Part 30, rule 5)

leg:heading.title: Sheriff may require security for costs of execution (cf DCR Part 34, rule 7; LCR Part 30, rule 5)

p.text: At any time after receiving a writ of execution, the Sheriff may require the judgment creditor:
to lodge such security for payment of the Sheriff’s costs in relation to the execution of the writ, or
to give such undertaking as to payment of the Sheriff’s costs in relation to the execution of the writ,
as the Sheriff considers appropriate.
If the judgment creditor fails to comply with such a requirement, the Sheriff:
may refuse to execute the writ, and
may withdraw from any possession into which the Sheriff may have entered under the writ.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 39.18] r 39.18 Sheriff to serve copy of writ when executing or attempting to execute writ (cf DCR Part 34, rule 5)

leg:heading.title: Sheriff to serve copy of writ when executing or attempting to execute writ (cf DCR Part 34, rule 5)

p.text: On executing a writ of execution, the Sheriff must cause a copy of the writ to be served on the judgment debtor or left in a conspicuous position at the place where the writ was executed.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 39.19] r 39.19 When writ may not be executed (cf DCR Part 34, rule 10)

leg:heading.title: When writ may not be executed (cf DCR Part 34, rule 10)

p.text: A writ of execution may not be executed on Christmas Day or Good Friday.
The Sheriff is not required to execute a writ of execution on any day on which court registries need not be open.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 39.20] r 39.20 Expiry and renewal of writ of execution (cf SCR Part 44, rule 8; DCR Part 34, rule 2; LCR Part 30, rule 1, Part 30A, rule 2)

leg:heading.title: Expiry and renewal of writ of execution (cf SCR Part 44, rule 8; DCR Part 34, rule 2; LCR Part 30, rule 1, Part 30A, rule 2)

p.text: A writ of execution has effect for 12 months but may, subject to these rules, be renewed by the court.
[r 39.20 am Amendment 10 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[9], effective 7 July 2006]

In the absence of any express limitation a writ of execution would remain in force until it was completely executed: R v Sheriff of Essex (1839) 6 Bing NC 150; Jordan v Binckes (1849) 13 QB 757 . The application for extension is usually only made where it is desired to preserve the priority of the original writ: Re Broughton (1916) 17 SR (NSW) 29. The application may be made even after the writ has expired: Stutt v Smith (1888) 10 ALT 159 . The time limitation only applies to writs of execution as defined in the Civil Procedure Act 2005. It therefore does not apply, for example, to an order in a custody matter directing a court officer to take the ward of court into his or her possession and to deliver the ward to the person named in the order: St John v Smith (NSWSC, Young J, ED 1117/82, 30 May 1985, unreported, BC8500798).
